## `schoRsch`

::: {layout="[70,30]"}
::: first-column
Intended for ["cutting and pasting" into a processor](https://www.tqmp.org/RegularArticles/vol12-2/p147/p147.pdf) such as Word - not ideal for inline reporting for reproducible research. 
:::

::: second
Supports:

   + t test
   + ANOVA
   + $\chi^2$
   + correlation
:::
:::

## `apa`

```{r, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(psych)
library(apa)
data(bfi)

bfi$a<- rowMeans(bfi[1:5], na.rm=TRUE)
bfi$gender <- as.factor(as.character(bfi$gender))

analysis <- t.test(a ~ gender, data = bfi, var.equal=TRUE)

## Trying the `apa` t-test wrapper here, `r apa(analysis)` 

```

Wrapper is simply, `apa()`. Last week mistake was trying to use the `t_apa()` function (which produces similar output, but perhaps not intended for rMarkdown/Quarto).

Trying the `apa` t-test wrapper here: `r apa(analysis)`

## testing

```{r, echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE, R.options=list(width=10)}
library(psych)
library(apa)
data(bfi)

bfi$a<- rowMeans(bfi[1:5], na.rm=TRUE)
bfi$gender <- as.factor(as.character(bfi$gender))

analysis <- t.test(a ~ gender, data = bfi, var.equal=TRUE)

## Trying the `apa` t-test wrapper here: `r apa(analysis)` 

```

## `jtools` Figures

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| output-location: column-fragment
#| collapse: true
#| code-line-numbers: "10"
## jtools
## papaja
## local template

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length,      #<1>
      Sepal.Width)) +               #<1>
      geom_jitter() +               #<1>
      jtools::theme_apa()
```

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| output-location: column-fragment

## papaja

library(ggplot2)

      Sepal.Width)) +
      geom_jitter() + 
      papaja::theme_apa()        #<1>
```
1. `papaja` and `jtools` share the same function name, "theme_apa()"
